thread.title: Wild swimming in the Lake District
thread.title_full: Wild swimming in the Lake District | The Sunday Times

author: Duncan Craig
title: Wild swimming in the Lake District
text:
We gather in a huddle by the shore. The rain’s not far off horizontal, a ragged mist hangs over the featureless expanse of Wastwater, and our wetsuits and woolly hats are proving no match for the gnawing cold. It’s June, going on December. We’re here to swim eight of the biggest lakes in the western Lake District as part of a new three-day tour. A “swim bus” — think standard bus, only with hot chocolate on tap and a more tolerant driver — ferries us between them. But right now there’s a danger we won’t be swimming any of them.
There’s a loud creak, the minibus rocks on its axle, and Carlisle dairy farmer and fellow swimmer Jim steps out. His wetsuit hangs loosely around his portly midriff, and he’s whistling. “Let’s be having you, then,” he says before ambling down to the water, tugging up his neoprene and plunging in. Bugger.
